documents.title: this is all for today
text: thank you all very much for your questions , and thanks very much to neel for taking the time to answer them .
stay tuned for our coverage of the 2014 man booker prize winner , to be announced tomorrow .
cheers !
guardian contributor neelmukherjee 13 october 2014 3:41pm ok , i have to run off to do something now .
thank you all for your sharp , intelligent questions and for your engagement with my book .
it makes all the difference .
lingomat says : thank you again for writing such a wonderful book .
the question i would have had after now finishing your book ( i am the german woman from bath ) has been answered by your answer to paintedjaguar .
i wish you all the very best .
guardian contributor neelmukherjee 13 october 2014 3:31pm i remember you very well .
and i thank you again from the bottom of my heart .
cyandell asks : do you see yourself as writing in a particular tradition ?
and who are your literary heroes .
guardian contributor neelmukherjee 13 october 2014 3:29pm no , not in any particular tradition .
i 've written two realist novels but i may change course soon .
literary heroes - i have so many that we do n't have enough time in the world for this .
off the top of my head : george eliot , henry james , tolstoy , turgenev , bulgakov , beckett , penelope fitzgerald , heinrich boll , patrick white , anna akhmatova , w.g .
sebald

documents.title: `` i do n't read my books so i do n't allow myself the dangerous luxury of toying with the idea of doing things differently ''
text: posh33 asks : which part/ character/ episode of the lives of others proved to be the most difficult to write , and why ?
is there any section of the novel that you would write differently were you to write it again ?
guardian contributor neelmukherjee 13 october 2014 3:24pm most difficult character to write : probably adinath .

as for difficult parts/episodes , the funny thing is that once you 've overcome something that proved hard to write , you tend to see it as a lovely challenge , as something intellectually and creatively entertaining and satisfying .
i do n't read my books so i do n't allow myself the dangerous luxury of toying with the idea of doing things differently .
besides , you have to put the current book behind you if you are to begin the next one
posh33 asks : have you been following the debate over creative writing courses triggered off by the comments by the sweidish academy member about creative writing courses killing western literature ?
where do you stand on this ?
guardian contributor neelmukherjee 13 october 2014 3:15pm firmly with the honourable member of the swedish academy .
indranil chowdhury akks : hi neel , my question is , is it necessary to live the lives of others to feel for the others ?
does one have to go through the back breaking work of the peasants to understand that the world has to change ?
lastly , why would a communist like supratik be happy to hear that sona might go to us for higher studies ?
guardian contributor neelmukherjee 13 october 2014 3:12pm answer to your first and second questions : no ; imagination/empathy can take you there .

the third question : i had n't thought of this while writing my book but now that you pose this question , my retrospective answer would be this : like all of us , supratik holds a lot of contradictions inside himself ; 'contains multitudes ' , in short .
or perhaps the trade-off between his ideology and a better life for sona was the outcome you read of in the novel .
posh33 asks : how do you look at life after october 14 ?
guardian contributor neelmukherjee 13 october 2014 3:04pm as a return to my usual quiet life of reading .
cyandell asks : the lives of others is quite a long novel .
do you have a sense of a proper length for fiction - by which i mean , do some stories intrinsically demand more or less space ?
guardian contributor neelmukherjee 13 october 2014 3:03pm 'proper length for fiction ' i can safely declare to the world that that rule does n't exist .
liberation , hurrah .
posh33 asks : you are an author who treads this twilight zone where you write about a people and society and country that you no longer physically inhabit .
so who does neel mukherjee write for ?
and whose reaction/ criticism/ feedback matters to him the most ?

guardian contributor neelmukherjee 13 october 2014 3:01pm did hilary mantel have access to a kind of teleportation technology when she wanted to write about a people and society and country that she physically does not inhabit ' , ie , sixteenth-century england ?
this must be the literary world 's best-kept secret and i demand to be let in !
now .
posh33 asks : hi neel , you 've been quite a prolific literary critic .
is it difficult now being on the other side of the fence ?
how did you find the reviews of the lives of others ' that have come out so far ?
is it possible for an author who is also a critic to be objective about his own novel ?
guardian contributor neelmukherjee 13 october 2014 2:59pm i would n't call myself a literary critic ' , just a book reviewer .
i think i 've been mostly very lucky with the reviews of the lives of others ' .
as for being objective about one 's work is that a desirable thing to be ?
or , to put it another way , why would one want to be objective about one 's work ?
zarasilk asks : dear neel , i heard you on the bbc world service last night speaking about the importance of anger .
in which domains do you think this should happen , and what form do you think this anger should take ?
how are you defining anger ?
it seems to me that there is a lot of anger in the world of politics already .
i am all for organised opposition to systems of oppression , but unthinking anger is a dangerous force in the world , i think .

best regards , zara guardian contributor neelmukherjee 13 october 2014 2:57pm i do n't think there is a lot of anger in the world of politics ' , but quiescence , capitulation , and the play of power instead .
unthinking anger ' is a hypostasized pairing .
do n't you think anger can be more powerful and useful when it is of the thinking ' variety ?
perhaps the question to ask when you are dismayed by manifestations of anger is the question one must always ask , of every single thing : why .
as in : why are these people angry ?
the answers may lead you to uncouple that pairing of anger ' with unthinking ' .
i also think it 's useful to ask who it is that stands to benefit from the demonization of anger , from getting everyone to view , with unthinking homogeneity , anger as a negative emotion/force .
justinejordan asks : hello , neel , thanks for joining us .
in your piece for the guardian about the inspiration behind the lives of others , you ask , what has happened to the political novel in the anglo-american world ?
i 'd be fascinated to hear a bit more about this , and which contemporary works succeed as political novels .
thankyou !
guardian contributor neelmukherjee 13 october 2014 2:55pm thank you for inviting me to my first web chat .
i find myself afflicted by a first date stripe of nervousness .
to answer your question : now that i 've asked that question about the political novel , i 'm discovering political novels everywhere i look !
i meant to use the term political ' in the way ken loach , introducing krszysztof kieslowski 's film blue , described it as the way one learns to live , or survive , in the world ' .
i see philip roth 's american pastoral , i married a communist , and the human stain as inalienably political novels .
claire messud 's the emperor 's children and the woman upstairs are political books , as is everything that j.m coetzee writes .
but there 's politics and there 's politics .

i prefer to reserve the term political novel ' for novels that eschew the current affairs take on politics the 9/11 novel , the arab spring novel , the troubles novel , the immigrant novel , etc and opt instead to explore the far more complex calculus of how the private and the public will always and inevitably be linked in one form and one only a circle .
charlotte jones asks : hi neel do you think there are particular expectations of you as a writer from the indian subcontinent in terms of subject and form ?
if so , how does this impact on your writing ?
guardian contributor neelmukherjee 13 october 2014 2:53pm i do n't think i would call them expectations but there does seem to be a set of particular responses to writing from the subcontinent .
the trick is to liberate oneself from them .
as i said in reply to another person posting on this thread one writes what one can , or must , write .

paintedjaguar asks : i have n't read the ghosh review , but it seems to me ( and i may be projecting my own values onto the book here ) that the epilogue offers no more than the chilling truth that violence begets violence ; this kaleidoscopic book is therefore as far from being a celebration of supratik 's life as it can be .
so , yes , some general thoughts on this would be welcome .
thank you .
guardian contributor neelmukherjee 13 october 2014 2:49pm thank you for your comment .

for a novel that is so much about the inextricability of the private and the public or the personal and the political , if you will it had to have a final sounding of that major chord but in a transposed way .
supratik leaves behind a legacy in each of these domains , the private ( epilogue i ) and the public ( epilogue ii ) .
although one could argue fruitfully that subsumed in each of those domains there are private and public forces/consequences/causalities that are independent of supratik 's actions .
elpis2 asks : the opening of the lives of others is almost cinematic : it seems to sit quite outside the rest of the novel , even though the scene is so pertinent .
as a device , i think it works brilliantly , but i 'm curious about when , during the writing process , you decided to put that scene there .
guardian contributor neelmukherjee 13 october 2014 2:46pm thank you for your generous words about the opening scene .
i write chronologically ( for the most part ) , so that the scene you mention came at the very early stages of writing the book .
sabbirazam asks : dear neel-da , i 'm writing you from dhaka .
i have n't had the opportunity to read your novel yet .
your novel is set in naxalite period and most of the writers ( and filmmakers ) from kolkata have dealt with this period according to their own vision and thought on this issue .
what you were trying to achieve through this novel ?

it can be presumed that the response from the readers within india ( and bangladesh since we learn it through a lot of reading ) , who witnessed this period and outside india will be varied divergently .
how do you feel about this fact ?

in his review mr. ghosh writes what neel chooses to celebrate about supratik 's life is not the transmission of a spirit of resistance but rather a particular means of resisting i have n't read your book .
but it seems to me mr. ghosh tries to impose his own imagination and vision upon your protagonist .
rather you tried to de the real story or what a naxalite did during that time .
would you pls comment on this ?
thanks !
guardian contributor neelmukherjee 13 october 2014 2:45pm there are several questions here and i shall attempt to answer all of them .
your first one is potentially the longest one but the most truthful answer to it is the shortest of the lot : the novel itself is what i was trying to achieve ' .
if i had another way of articulating it , i would n't have written this book.your second one : you 're in trouble if everyone has the same response to your novel .
divergent and varied opinions are good.the last one is a question for amitav ghosh , not for me .
surely his view is part of that choir of varied and diverging interpretations that you mentioned earlier ?
this is what keeps literary criticism alive and thriving instead of solidifying into a crushing monolith .
erik glantz asks : hello , neel .
i was pleased with your view of the novel as a moral educational experience requiring empathy with characters in many roles .
but agents usually reject such things because publishers do , because publishers are oligarchs and readers do n't want to hear about moral encumbrances or sad things .
must we add only little bits of enlightenment to romances and detective novels , or is there a market for richly instructive stories ?
how is too much challenge avoided ?

guardian contributor neelmukherjee 13 october 2014 2:44pm i was trying to say something about the moral energy of the novel form but since your questions are more purposive , i shall endeavour to answer them .
one writes what one can , or has to , write .
the rest is up to chance .
never try to second-guess what an industry , or literary fashion , or the market ' ( that great unknown , much like death ) might want .
remember that what seems zeitgeisty today is the cause of tomorrow 's bafflement or , worse , ridicule .

documents.title: neel is with us now
text: thanks the questions that have already been coming in and apologies for the slight delay , due to our technical problems .
here is neel !
guardian contributor neelmukherjee 13 october 2014 2:43pm sorry about the delay- the old luddite in me is still alive and kicking .
thank you for being here today and thank you for your interest in my book .
neel mukherjee terrifies and delights us simultaneously , wrote as byatt , reviewing the lives of others for the guardian .

this ambitious third novel , set in calcutta in the late 1960s , evokes the cliche of the indian family saga and then slyly undercuts it with a second , epistolary narrative of political activism in bengal at a time of social upheaval and gross social injustice .
at the centre of the novel are the ghosh family an industrial dynasty uneasily cohabiting in a large house , quartered to reflect their stations .
this uncomfortable status quo is challenged by the defection of a grandson to the naxalite guerrilla movement .
one of mukherjee 's great gifts is precisely his capacity to imagine the lives of others .
he can move from inside one head to inside another in a conversation or conflict and take the reader with him , wrote byatt .
mukherjee was born in calcutta in 1970 and moved to the uk in his early 20s .
the historical and cultural accuracy of the novel was praised by novelist amitav ghosh , a fellow bengali , who described it as an unforgettably vivid of a time of turmoil . '
neel will be online from 2.30pm-3.30pm bst on monday 13 october and will endeavour to answer all your questions .
